                                  IN CONNECTION WITH ALL OTHER LINES IN THE UNITED STATES AND CANADAS.
                           Terms and Conditions on which Message are received by this Company for transmissions:

The public are notified, that, in order to guard against mistakes in the transmission of messages, every message of importance ought to be repeated, by being sent back from the station at which it is to be received to the station from which it is originally sent. Half the usual price for transmission will be charged for repeating the message. The Company will not be responsible for mistakes or delays in the transmission or delivery of unrepeated messages, from whatever cause they may arise. not will it be responsible for damages arising from mistakes  or delays in transmission or delivery of a repeated message, beyond an amount exceeding two hundred times the amount paid for sending the message  nor will it be responsible for delays arising from interruptions in the working of its Telegraphs, nor any mistake or omission of any other Company over whose lines a message is to be sent to reach the place of destination. All messages will hereafter be received by this Company for transmission, subject to the above conditions.
J.D. CATON, Pres.'t, Ottawa, Ill.    
By Telegraph from Elyria O 19 Feby.  1863
To. I.S. Metcalf

                          Children unwell not not dangerously But we need your aid
                                                                                                                              A.P. Metcalf

Nettie
Elyria
March 18, '63
Elyria, Wednesday, March 18, 1863 --
Dear Isaac,
Here we are all about the little table in the sitting room - baby in the carriage close by me - May & the three boys - It is just after supper time and grandmother is reading to them from Pilgrim's Progress, in which they are much interested She reads half an hour every Evening - We are all doing well baby was not very well yesterday - vomited twice but she fells nicely to day - Charlie wants me to say that he piled up all the wood Charlie Rich saved & split to day - I've just put May to bed - you know she plays come visiting with her babies and knocks for me to notice her - this P.M. she came and knocked on the back of my chair, when I was busy reading & watching baby, and minded nothing about

her till I suppose she had knocked several times. Finally she raised her voice quite high and, knocking again, said "Knock and it shall be opened unto you, and here I stand knocking" - Dr was up to day & I told him of it and he laughed heartily.  He came up to find the top to his umbrella that Libbie lost off going home from school. She stopped here on the way home.  I showed him your new book on gardening, in which he was interested.  Anna was up yesterday she is very busy getting Hattie ready to go to Ills.  She is going to Cleveland next week stops there a day or two. Sarah Converse goes to Cleveland tomorrow morning not to return here. Mother has got almost a new jacket made for Charlie Rich & it looks nicely.  I went into school yesterday A.M. and heard Weldins class in geog. and the B. class in Arithmetic of Mrs. Parker's, and a class in spelling of Miss Smiths - all did well - I like Mrs Parker.  She seems to understand character pretty well.  Good night - Your Nettie

Saturday Eve, March 21 - 
1863
My dearest - 
Half past nine, and all are gone to bed but me, and I only linger to write a very little to you.  I wanted a letter from you to night but it did not come - I got one yesterday, written at Indianapolis. We are all well as usual - Little May seems decidedly gaining.  I do not know as she really needs her medicine - have not sent for it yet. She went over to Mr Mussey's Thursday morning, with grandmother, and it did her no damage, that we can perceive. Mr & Mrs Parker & Mary D - called here Thursday Eve about nine o'clock (after meeting) to look over our engravings for tableaux

for exhibition - They took four to Mrs Parker's room to examine and perhaps copy after. Anna thinks Mary D. will hardly be able to walk so far to school next term - the weather being warmer. She thinks she will wish a change on that account. We had a traveller - a man with a big pack on his back Thursday eve, between eight & nine He wanted to sleep in the kitchen We did not know where to send him but Charley Rich waited on him down town, & I guess he got attended too somehow -  Sabbath 22 March - I have been to the AM meeting - grandmother did not want to go - her head ached - so I went with the three boys - John Monteith was there, and listened to an excellent sermon from Mr Wilbur said John, is to preach this evening.  This is a very summer like day.

The warmest day we have had by considerable - Mr Philemon Bliss was at church - looking pale and thin - do not know when he arrived.  Baby has been vomiting to day again - grandmother thinks it is her teeth.  Mr. Wilburs text - was "Verily, Verily I say unto you They have their reward" - All the reward they wished or would have - praise and applause of men. And this is exhaustive. They have it only for a time.  Then it is gone - and nothing comes in its place.  Monday morn - I expect you will be amused at my letter, for I have written just as I had time, and some with baby in my lap - We had a hard rain all night long with considerable thunder and lightening - It does not rain this morning but looks as if it might. Charlie Rich is going down town

this morning to get a few potatoes. Mr Waldo had none to spare. Mr Waldo has worked on the Manure part of two days. Our chimney burnt out, with a fury, this morning.  Caught in the furnace pipe first - it was red hot.  I heard John Monteith last eve - Text - salute Tryphene & Triphosa, and the beloved Persis &c I don't know as I have any of it quite right.  Mr and Mrs Monteith, Senr. are coming to Elyria to live again.  Hope I shall get a letter from you to day - I'll send this by Charlie Rich this morning - Lovingly, Nettie

Elyria, Tuesday, March 24
1863 - 
My dear Isaac, -
Yours of the 20th with the letter enclosed for Charles R. Metcalf arrived to day - The little boys enjoyed their part - very much - Wilder as much as Charlie perhaps, because he was the big brother, to read it.  We do hope you can return this week but I was saying to mother just now that I would not expect you - The Chicago Draft arrived.  I did as you said with it, and acknowledged the receipt of it to the C. D. Austin who forwarded it. Hattie De Witt goes to Cleveland Sat. & to Ills next week. Pity they couldn't have gone with you - Rollin too, is going out on business in July - It has been quite warm since the Sabbath, but rained some yesterday morning, and is raining now again.  I am reading as I have time Spencers

book on education - Rather phlosophical in the beginning, but very pleasant - & useful reading it is, in some things, a book after your own heart. Some ideas about the value of a practical education in place of "dead languages" &c, would suit my father expertly.  Grandmother has finished the jacket - out of the old coat for Charlie Rich. The boy never will know what he owes his grandmother - not so much for patient remodelling of old coats & pants, however, as for higher and nobler good - if he only grows up, as doubless he will, a good and true man, she will feel paid.  In haste your own Nettie M
[upside down] Nettie Elyria
March 24 63
Mr. Metcalf, Present  written in lighter ink  above 3rd to last line

My dear Father --
It made me jump to see the nice letter for me from you - Wilder read it to me, and we both kissed little Anna very softly and told her father sent it. She has been a little sick, since you went away. The wind blew very hard this forenoon and when I tried to hold our Christmas Tree, so that Wilder could make it stand up, I could'nt hold it, and had to blow a little ways with it.  It is pretty warm here now. I was so warm, when I came home from church Sabbath day, that I could'nt keep my coat buttoned and yesterday we sat in the sitting room

with the door open, a good while.  This afternoon it rains again. One day Old Mary got loose somehow, and went all about the lane and the Biggs lot with her halter dragging, & Mr Waldo cought her and put her in the barn. I wish I was in Ills. with you - I try to help mother. I have piled up a good deal of wood for Charlie Rich, and Wilder & I helped Gertrude set the table. I am trying to learn not to strike anybody. Wilder and I went to Aunty Jenney's to carry a letter and to Aunt Anna's to get a book and the rains cought us and we got our pants wet. O the flowers are out, but not a great many and some little red berries in the grove, but not very big.  Your little boy, Charlie -

Saturday Aug 30 1863
Dear Isaac,
I will write a little this morning - for if you do not get leave to come home to day you will be glad to hear from us and all - Eliab continued to gain, and left by way of Grafton for Sandwich Thursday about half past four. Concluded to give up going to Cincinnati. He could not have gained much strength for he had eaten no solid foods - but said he felt perfectly well - We tried to persuade him to remain till your return. Wednesday A.M about half past eleven the Grafton hack brought our cousin Mary Barber who looks a little like Abby Dickinson, appears very well indeed, and

will I imagine prove a useful and pleasant member of this family - she is a very decided Baptist Christian.  Brought a letter of introduction from the Lanesville? minister to our Mr Leonard, and I went there with her yesterday to carry it with her. She seemed quite anxious to see him - but he happened to be out.  We saw Mrs Leonard and, by the way she is very lovely - I had never seen her before.  The children are well as usual. Charlie Rich studies some every day, and cousin Mary is going to help him.  We had a nice rain yesterday P.M and in the night.  Did it make you get cold to be in tents on such a damp night I fear it will. Mr. Waldo fixed the pump

yesterday, and it does pretty will. Mr Renfield called to see Eliab, about an hour after he left, and yesterday Mr Wilbur called to see him & you, not remembering you were to be away so long.  Dr. De Witt says David Baldwin is home & Dr Gushing - I went to Anna's to supper last night with Mary Barber.  The Catholic School is again opened - cousin Mary sews for me - We shall all be glad enough if you can get home to day.  Loving Nettie - Anna says she is gaining slowly -

Nettie
Aug. 31 1863
To Camp Cuyahoga Elyria, Monday, Aug. 31 1863
My dearest,
Charlie Rich is reciting his spelling lesson to Mary Barber and baby is asleep - so I'll scribble a little to tell you we are well, and wishing very much for your return I went to my meeting and cousin Mary went to hers yesterday - I gave the library key to Mr Brooks - Dr De Witt told me Mr Brooks seemed a little offended in some way about session room after Mr Johnson had agreed with the Building Com. I hope it is not really so. How did you get along the cold rainy nights we have had?  I was "divided between two" about the nice, big, warm coat you had - I was so glad you had such an article to frighten away the

rheumatism, and sorry that Eliab had not one just as warm but I hope he has not suffered for lack of it.  Since I began this I've had all sorts of callers, and now must hurry very much to get it ready.  I enclose these circulars - they came last week - did'nt know but you might do something with them where you are. A long letter from Mr Keyes, and two deeds came Friday - favorable rather than otherwise, I should think, about the mines. If you can look out something for Charlie Rich a jacket I hope you will - And I should be glad if you would think best to get an oil cloth or a carpet suiting your own good taste, for

our dining room - We do need it. Mr Keyes is going to send you some money right away.  You doubtless know your standing before now in the P.M. Herbert wispered it to me yesterday.  I hope for a little letter to night, to tell when you are coming - every body asks.  I've had a busy, hurried time since you left - good many callers &c - but get along nicely with it all - Boys have been picking up apples to day C. Rich mowing & gelling in hay - Baby & May just now down to Anna's with cousin Mary - I see Proctor and a team are at work to day on S.House grounds - Mr Parker gone to Camden to Institute - your own Nettie

Nettie
Dec 4 1863
Elyria, Dec. 11 1863
My dearest,
I received yesterday a remarkably stiff epistle; naetheless it was extremely welcomed. I suppose by now, you are at Du Quoin safe and sound I hope. We are all well as when you left. Charlie & Wilder went this morning to the pasture with the animals without trouble.  The weather is quite mild & sunny. I am going to give baby a ride down to Aunt Anna's this P.M. Grandmother is going down a little while. The plaster is pretty dry in the new room - seems quite firm - floor not yet laid. I am to have the

a short time this morning - cousin Mary wishes very much she could take Miss Pinney's place.  Yesterday we put the cradle away in Gertrude's bedroom & then showed baby that it was gone - all gone, and she must sleep with mother in the bed. It took me a long time to get her to sleep & she cried a good deal in the night, but I got through with it - hope she may do better to night - I have written this with baby in my arms as you may imagine - but cousin Mary has her now - I went to Anna's with her a little while All are well there -.
Mr Jenkins address is
Capt L. L. Jenkins
16th Reg. Corps d'Afrique
2 Div 13th Army Corps
via N. Orleans - La

I think Charlie R - will do the best he can with the cow - Little Charlie is coping with toothache again to night - I hardly know what to do with him - Wilder succeeded in going till Thursday night without a check but to day (Friday) he got one. I felt very sorry he did not make out the week - so did he.  I went into his school Wednesday, and talked with Miss Smith about Wilder & feel some better.  I cannot help feeling anxious about Wilder. I hope we may do wisely with our children - I feel like a child myself when I think of training boys and girls to be good & to be useful - God only can make them desire to be truly good.  I must stop - Charlie cries with his tooth, and it is sleepy time for baby  Truly and lovingly your Nettie

Nettie
Dec 6 1863
Elyria, Dec 6 - 1863
Dear Isaac - 
I am sitting all alone in the dining room.  Baby and Charles sleeping very nicely on the bed in our room - Mother and Charley Rich & Mary as well as Wilder all up stairs,  Baby has slept three nights now, in the bed and done very well. The darling is gaining in health, and consequently in spirit - she is quite lovely. I went this evening to monthly Concert Instead of the old round of "Missionary Intelligence" Mr Wilbur lectured on the first Missionary tour of St. Paul. There were an unusual number to hear, and it was good. is to be continued Notice to day of "Divine Circle" at Dr. Strongs next Friday evening. I stopped to Sabbath School to day and, in the

absence of Mrs Boyd, was urgently requested to hear my old class, and did so.  Quite a full school.  Miss Eliza Wheeler acted in her capacity as Treasurer, it being the 1st Sab of the month - she will finish up next Sabbath.  I had a letter from Mary Dascomb yesterday - to say she had decided no to come here at present.  In the first place she says Caesar is sold - 2' The roads are dreadful & the way long round by Cleveland. Then there is especial interest in the S.S. and she is just commencing Music lessons and joining a singing Class - I am very sorry she is not coming - shall write her to reverse the decision.  Mother had a letter from Maria yesterday - All well - Eliab is going to build a ship.

Monday Many people ask when you will return - It seems to be thought that there is important school matter to come up - I do not know what - cousin Mary has been quite inclined to apply for Miss Penney's place - we have not encouraged it - not knowing what was best about it. Fence about school house grounds is about completed I think - no one has been here to do any work since you left. Mrs Mussey is still quite sick - she had severe dysentery, prostrating her very much.  Mother is here now, but talks some of going back to Anna's in a day or two.  Miss Wheeler has been twice to me to ask me to tell you about some money paid on their slip in chh - that you had not acknowledged - I told

her you would make it all right when you come.  - Wilders letter came this noon.  He was delighted.  I think he tries to be good, but finds it hard work. May is learning to read fast.  Give love to Mrs Keyes & family. I suppose you will see Mrs Root - before you return.  Very lovingly, your Nettie - May says she wishes she could write a letter, and the beginning of it - be - my dear Father.  I asked Anna if she would send a kiss to papa, and she put up her little mouth at once to kiss, and then said, "Where" in her pretty way.  Here come Wilder from school - without a check - so he has begun the week well.  Charlie Rich is just speaking his 'peice' for examination.  All send love to dear Isaac with ever so many good wishes

Nettie 
Dec. 10 1863
Elyria, Ohio
Thursday, Dec. 10 - 1863
My own dearest,
The wee ones all in their beds - I sit me down to talk with my pen to you. The children all seem to have severe colds, But are not really sick, and I imagine will not be - I do not see why they take cold so very easily - Baby has not got those upper teeth yet - They have seemed just about through a long time - To day closed the Secondary School. I went in & mother also. Wilder spoke his peice, very well, showing however that he was somewhat frightened. He got no check this week - and he exalts considerably over, thirty anticipated cents. The Calkins trial is over and he is brought in guilty again - and

is sentenced thirty days in jail and two years in state prison.The relatives feel terribly about it. No body has done a stroke of work here since you left. To day Mr Besis? brought a load of siding, and I think he may come tomorrow and put it on. The bedstead came Tuesday - it looks well.  Mr Wilbur was in school, and Mr. Gates was there, and regretted the absence of the President of the Board and said he would act as Lieut - in your absence - did'nt make so much of a speech as usual.
[on side]:  Messrs Griswold & Troodtes? were there
There seems not to be much to write about - We all want to see you a good deal - perhaps more than that. Grandmother sits here knitting for the S.A. Fair. Anna is pretty busy at home now, till Libby gets out

of school, because last Sabbath Maggie went home to begin going to school.  The Divine Circle is to meet at Dr. Strongs tomorrow eve = There is quite a long letter from Mr Jenkins in the Democrat of this week - Mrs Parker called here last night. They leave next Monday for Granville, to spend the whole vacation. I did not mention that Mr Rush was in school and speechified as usual in his soft way to this clear young friends.  Please do you want Charlie Rich to dry up the cow? The feed of now a days increases her milk. Here is Gertrude with a letter from Almeda for mother, and one for me from yourself - just what I wanted - It was written last Monday - and you had no letters from me.  I've sent two, and you

have one before now, doubtless. We had a laugh over your Irish curate. But you say no word about coming home.  there is a great grandchild at Brownsville for our mother - a little girl, that James thinks is really pretty - born Nov 9. Lirren writes that the wolves ate up two of their sheep not very far from the barn.  I hope you are well and comfortable to night. O how much I have to be thankful for - If the children are not severely sick this winter, won't it be good. Good night - from your loving Nettie -
Friday - All comfortable this morning - Baby sleeps nicely in bed - Cousin Mary gone over to Grammar school examinations - Wilder gone to school with little Charlie -  Baby sets on the lounge singing very sweetly to herself - May is building houses on the floor - calling me to her now & then - Mr Bezir? hammering at the floor in new bedroom

Nettie
Dec 14 1865
Elyria, Ohio - Monday eve - Dec 14
Dear Isaac -

Two weeks tomorrow since you left - It really seems at least twice as long - Yours of Dec 8 - to Wilder and me came today - giving us all great pleasure - Wilder could hardly believe that there could be for his another letter - "What -", said he "Another, do you mean, beside the one I had the other day" - Then when I said yes his face looked very bright indeed - He read all except three of four words himself - It was very handsomely & plainly written - He will write in reply in a few days at least, unless you write that you are coming home - You say not a

word about it yet.  Yesterday I went to meeting & to Sabbath school - Miss Wheeler was busy about the notes - I believe did not quite finish - some forgot to bring what they owed Mr Brooks thought he would wait over one more Sabbath, before sending for papers, to see if you wouldn't be here - talks of sending for Well Spring  Mr Bezir finished the floor and ceiling of new room this morning except a place needing planing in the floor - He hung the blinds, but did not set the windows out, for I could not get all arranged before Wednesday, and thought I would prefer to have the window where it is till after Society - You said nothing about painting - Holcomb has reset the broken pane, and said he could go right to painting the new room, but I told him, unless you spoke

to him to do it, I should rather wait till you return - The bedstead came, before tho Bezir came, and looks nicely - shall make a new tick, and set it up after Society - Shall not need to make anything else new for it. I had a letter from father today - He had received yours, and directed an answer to Du Quoin - I had too a letter from Cousin France Putnam - She is Assistant in a grammar school in East Cambridge, has with a salary of $350.00 per year - to be increased to $400.00 after the first year - Carrie is still teaching at Worcester - Cousin Mary said she felt a little disappointed at first about the place in the grammar school, but she thinks it is all right and best now - She is a dear, good girl - She sends love

and Mother says "my love and blessing for the dear boy" -  Charles Rich has been getting in turnips today and Wilder helping some - It has been a cold, raw windy day - rained all night has rained a good part of the time since last Thursday night -  Tuesday morn - Quite a cold morning - The boys have been busy as bees all the morning writing letters to father  - All well this morning only colds - Baby's teeth not through yet -   Loving  Nettie -

Eleven dollars and a half taken at Dr Strong's at Divine circle last Friday eve. I did not go.
Friday A.M.  Cold & blustery - Charlie has just been up and got the cattle - If it moderates he can drive them past you
[upside down]: 
Ladies Present at Sewing Circle
at Mrs. Col. Metcalf's
Dec_16_1863

Nettie
Dec 17 1863

Elyria, Ohio -
Thursday, Dec 17 - 1863

My dear Isaac

I do not know as another letter will reach you, but think I will write at any rate - Yours of Dec 10 came Tuesday morning - Quite a favorable account you gave of mining and its prospects - hope it may continue  I have paid Charlies school bill to Miss Crandall $250 - I got Dr to get me some two kinds of tea, & coffee last week in anticipation of Society - one Lb. of each - in amount - $3,05.  Yesterday the day Sewing Circle was appointed here was a very bad day - Steady snow storms all the afternoon, but we had a very pleasant, and pretty fully attended meeting, plenty

of work to do, and all went off well - Charlies silver brought a premium of eighty five cents. Doing pretty well wasnt it?  Mr Edwin Byington died and was buried last week - after a few days sickness - typhoid fever. Mr Bartless too, died of delirum tremens.  Mr Pond's people are greatly troubled  Mr Calkins is again brought in by the jury Guilty and sentenced to thirty days in jail and two years hard labor in Penitentiary and to pay costs - His wife is at Mr Ponds and goes every day to see him - She does not seem to feel it as much as Mrs Pond - Horace Pond is expected home very soon  His health fails and he is supposed to be in consumption - He has been to St Paul for his health, but had lost rather than gained thereby.

Mrs Pond says - "Trouble, trouble - it seems as if there was no end to it".  A letter came from the Adjutant General last night - The minutes of some Capt's Election in Amhurst was forwarded without a date - so that no commissions could be sent  I have done nothing about getting the new bed ready yet - Society meeting here this week, and tomorrow Charlies school closes, and I want to visit it - but that is to be  my next sewing - Mother sits here reading - Charlie R. making himself a writing desk - children all asleep - Anna has been up today - Dr came up yesterday to get plan for seating the Lecture Room - I couldnt find it - I think it cannot be here - hope he will find it elsewhere, for they didn't know where to put the partition without it - It has been stormy

about all the time for a week. The sun had hardly shone at all during that time -  Baby has no new tooth yet - The little thing has a hard time - She is quite restless at night  sometimes and cries considerable - She will not feel will till those teeth come through - May is quite interested in learning to read - Charlie seems quite fearful that she will get into the Second reader first - We have taken no pains with her either -  We are all hoping you will get home next week. Please give my love to the people I know  Charlie will go up to see the Cattle and carry salt & c  tomorrow I guess - Mother had a letter from Albina last night - All well - Harriet Kittridge just married to a Mr Ham of Cambridge, Ma. They fully mean to come to Elyria in March - and seem to hope for the Bliss farm   Great love from  Nettie

Some of the ladies remained till nine o'clock the day of sewing circle - When they left baby said "by" to them and as soon as they were really gone she said "there" with a sigh of relief

Nettie  Dec 20 1863
Elyria, Ohio
Sabbath evening. Dec 20/63
My dear Isaac

 I went to meeting this evening with Charlie Rich for company and heard Mr. Wilbur preach a good sermon on Annihilation - I did not go out in the A.M. so I do not know about Sabbath school, only that Mr Brooks still delays about the papers for your return. This has been a very cold day, but fair, and the evening glorious - I say very cold - it was perhaps 16 degrees above zero. We all hope before another Sabbath to see you - Wilder is quite ambitious about learning Bible lesson - he was greatly pleased with his letter about the coal mine  read it himself, and read for Charlie and May also - They all felt as if it was something quite grand to have

a letter all to themselves - I had a nice letter, at the same time your last came, from Mrs Root - If you see her please give her my love and tell her I was much gratified to hear from her - She seems to feel sad and it is not to be wondered at. Mrs Jenkins says her husband is now  Provost Marshall of Brazos Island - with several companions as Provost Guard.  A very fat letter came Friday from Columbus - military - I haven't opened it.  I think you will be pleased when you return to note the progress Charlie & May are making in reading - I think they both learn quite fast - Baby is gaining now in flesh and travels all about just as she used to - I was almost afraid to tell you how nicely she seems, last when her teeth come to prick through, she

should have another bad time. It is said we have more small pox here - in the small house where Mr Jenkins used to live - varioloid, but quite severe. There seems to be no fear of it spreading. I wish you were to be here Tuesday and Wednesday, to the great Fair for Soldier's Aid - Perhaps it is well for your pocket though - I do not know how much I ought to spend - It is to be in the Courthouse - I suppose we must all go and buy something - Edith Ely is propounded for admission to the church next communion  I wish Libby DeWitt & Charlie Rich were ready to come too -  Perhaps this will not reach you - all the better if it does not - I thought I would write lest you should be delayed -
Good night - Nettie -
P.S. Wont Mrs Keyes send me some Photographs? Please ask her she has yours and mine -

Elyria, Ohio Feb 23, 1865
My dear Isaac,
We were all glad to hear from you last night, but feel sorry for your misfortunes and hindrances. hope you got through safely to Du Quoin yesterday.  The folks all went up to Charles to dinner Tuesday as expected  baby and Anne remaining at home with me. May went up to the farm and enjoyed it very much and got very tired; but guess that on the whole it did her good.  Mr Bradford came up Tuesday P.M. with a letter and little package to send out to Mrs Root.  I felt sorry for his disappointment in finding you had gone.  You will find time to call on Mrs. Root, I hope it will so much gratify him.  He spoke of

people complaining some of Mr Wilbur's sermon at Mr. Darlings funeral.  
Eliab & Charles went over to A. Braman farm together, and had considerable talk about it.  Eliab thought he would give all it is worth for it, but that probably Mr. Braman would hold it higher than his estimate of it's value.  Eliab has gone up to Charles', again to day.  Charles took supper here with Eliab last night, and Dr. & Anna & Albina spent the evening with them.  Came as soon as Anne & Albina came from "Society".  Mrs. Patterson was here for help to day I sent her to Mr Hitchcock.  
We got along very well with the children last night, & Tuesday night also.  Anna was quite restless last night, but well enough to day, Mary

sleeps with me Mother seems well as usual.  I do hope all will be well with you.  hope you will get some good sound sleep.  do no sit up late, as you almost always do when out at Du Quoin. even if you must stay a day or two longer to make up for it.  Eliab has spoken of going tomorrow (Friday) but I reckon he will not.  will write again sometime this week. 
Your loving Nettie.

By way of Rollin De Witt, might perhaps be obtained.  Eliab likes Mrs Ely's residence & grounds.  says he wishes you were here.  Rollin De Witt said he wanted to see you very much, and was sorry you were away  He brought from N.York, where he has been for some weeks a silver plated coffee pot as a present to his father and mother. It is very elegant. and makes very nice coffee besides.  Charlie and Josie and Libbie have been spending the evening here. Mother is not quite as well as usual.  some cold. children about as when you left. I called on Mrs Launders on my way to Dr's and paid my debt.  It is about half past ten, and I will not finish till morning.

Eliab still thinks he must go Monday next.  We wish he could stay till you come.  Saturday home.  All well had a good sleep ,and feel rested.  Hope you are well and prospering.  perhaps a letter will come to night. to tell me so.
In haste, your Nettie

Elyria, Feb. 5, 1866.
My dearest,
The end of the day has come, and I sit down to tell you about it.  The one event of importance seems to be that this morning the dear "father of us", as Anna says, started for Ills.  She says too "what is the name of the way off where father has gone, and so she keeps trying to say Du Quoin.  Mr. Waldo came over to see you

about some chopping. but said he could perhaps do ti some other time as well.  Wilder & Charlie went down town and carried my letters to be mailed and brought up some salt, and Springfield Republican. two letter for Charles and one for me from Mrs Dascomb, only a half sheet, but crowded with family items.  Dr. lectures at Cleveland, but is home Sat. & Monday.  They had a letter by the pilot from Mary, in as good spirits, as could be expected considering she was sea sick.  Mrs D. spends the whole

day at the New Boarding Hall after the opening of the Spring term.  I wish we could go over there before it begins.  She is in search of a good woman to take charge of her domestic affairs. 

It is evening now. The boys are busy reading. May just about going to bed. Elisa has her clothes all dry & in the house.  I believe the pig and cow have had their regular rations & have been well cared for noon and night.  Eliza & Wilder are going down cellar now to take care of the furnace. carry down water

Tuesday morn. All well. nice bright morning.

bring up carrots etc.
I went into Mr. Toplift after Wilder came from school.  The children are getting over their sickness, and her girl is sick now, and has gone home.  Mrs. Cogswell there to help her. I went a few minutes to Mrs. Crandalls too, Mr Wilbur had been there, and they thought him discouraged and hardly knowing what to do next. I am afraid no body really holds up his hands. Still I cannot help thinking there is a good deal of the feeling, with a few at least, "I will not let thee go except thou bless me". 
Hope you are comfortable and prospering. suppose you will be riding all night.  Your loving Nettie
May  says only two in her class, were perfect for the month. herself & Lucy.

Ette's Feb. 6 1866
Elyria, Ohio
Tuesday, Feb 6, 1866
My dear Isaac,
A letter came to night for Charles from you.  He will not get it till morning. He was here about four with a load of wood, and Eliab was here. I guess two hours chopping. Charlie went down this morning with the mail to and to mail the letter to his father and was gone just half an hour.  Wilder wrote quite a nice letter to Percie before school.  He has learned

a short piece of prose to speak in school tomorrow P.M.  May too has learned a piece.  Willie came up and spent the forenoon with Anna.  They were eating nuts together and Willie wanted a piece of Annies.  "You can't get it now", she said, "for I swallowed it and it is down in my gut now".  Lizzie De Witt came up about eleven and spent the rest of the day.  We went together into Mr Mussay's a few minutes this P.M. It has been a very fine day, and this evening is beautiful.  It is not so cold as when you left.

I did not go out to meeting this eve.  baby was awake till nearly eight; and his double teeth make him some what fretful.  Eliza had has tooth ache considerable, but not very hard.  Eliab carried Maria & Anna to see that Norton place yesterday, and they liked it much. Mallie thought it almost a Paradise (so Lizzie said) I have not seen Maria or Anna since.
Good night 
You own Nettie

I sent some turkey to Mary Rich and Eliab had a taste after his chopping, and it is about all disposed of now. Lizzie seemed to enjoy it much at dinner today -
Wednesday morng  Baby and Anna slept all night long - I did not get out of bed at all till past five - Then Anna called out lustily "Farvo?, Farvo? twas here" -   Lovingly, Nettie -

Nettie
Feb 7 1866

 Elyria, Ohio
 Feb 7 1866

My dearest,

 I am just home from evening meeting (Wednesday) and have read Wilders letter which he has written entirely himself, while I have been away.. I went down to Mother's Meeting and Albina came home with me, to spend time between meetings. Eliab came up here quite early this morning and chopped all the A.M. Charles

came with a load of wood about Eleven, and got & read the letter from you about the boy  Mallie came up too about Eleven & went home at noon with Eliab. They were both invited to spend the day with Mrs Heman Ely - but Maria went with Mrs Ely from the Mother's Meeting, & Eliab down to tea & for the Evening instead of going before dinner  We had a good meeting in the afternoon - quite full - Mrs Vincent and Mrs Gallup were there - The meeting this evening was unusually good  Mr Carter, Crane, De Witt, Lantsbury, Nelson, Cogswell and Leonard took

part, beside reading & remarks about the Pearl of great price by Mr. Wilbur - Miss Benson & Mrs Wooster were there - Charlie Rich rose for prayers. Tomorrow he is Eighteen years old - I can but think he will become a Christian -  The boys have been very good and tried, I think, to be faithful about their work - and we get on as nicely as we could be expected to without "the dear father" -  In haste, your  Nettie -

Nettie                                                                                                                            Elyria, Ohio, Feb. 8, 1866
Feb. 8 1866

                My dearest -
                           A letter from yourself to night from Ind. We were all glad enough to hear. The children, to say nothing of myself, have been impatient for the first letter. We have got on very nicely. Eliza is so good & faithful. It has been snowing very softly & rapidly all day long and all this evening. I did not go down to meeting. I went down to Dr. about two hours & a half this P.M. They think Birdie & Nellie are to have the measles. Both are unwell and it seems like that. Maria is not well having taken cold. Little John is fretful & I thought a little feverish today. I think it is those double teeth just coming through. He sleeps nicely through the nights. Mary Rich came down this morning. She is gone to bed, as are all the rest.
  Wilder brought tonight a letter from your cousin Charles Wilder Stevens of Hornellsville Steuben Co. New York - requesting to know how & where to find you, as he is going out to Iowa, and says, "if suited there, I shall remain and practice law" He says too, "I understand that if I go the Lake Shore road, I pass

near the place in which you reside. If so, I should be very glad to visit you and Aunt Anna."

  He requests an answer, telling of your whereabouts, that he may be able to find you. I think perhaps you will write to him at once, when you receive this. He does not say a word about the time when he expects to go West. Perhaps I had better write too, right away, or get Eliab to do so.
   The children have been reading Youth's Companion to night, and enjoying it much. Mary & Wilder played one game of Checkers. Wilder thinks he is doing well at school in the matter of deportment. Don't know how near right he gets it.
        In haste,
               Your loving Nettie.

Friday morn} 
I will send that letter to Eliab this morning I guess, and ask him to answer it.

  We are all well this morning. The cow is fed & milked & the pig attended to and all ready to take the milk and the letter. Charlie is going this morning. Everything is snow covered - but it is not very cold - thawed some before the snow came. The ground is hardly covered.

Netty P. Metcalf 
Feb. 9 1866
Elyria, Ohio
Friday, Feb. 9, 1866
My dearest-
Half past eight Mary and I sit here by ourselves Elises & children all gone to bed - Mary went down to Dr's this P.M. Little Birdie she found quite sick - I believe they think it is Diptheria now - Marie is better - Nellie has quite a bad cough - Anne has answered the letter from the New York cousin - They all

hope he will come.
The weather has been warmer to day, and it seems like rain Charlie has been writing to you and May, - and little Anna wanted to write also - To gratify her I'll put in the paper she scribbles on. She took immense pains with it - She wrote on one piece of paper and then she copied it - I asked her to read it - So she read - "My dear father, - I love you very much & I want to see you. Don't you want to see Anna? Good by. From Anna" - So now you have the original manuscript and the interpretation thereof.

She has just waked & called to me to put a "silver hanchief" round her neck - So I have put a handkerchief round, and taken her up, and now she is quiet again -
I went over to Mr. Waldo's today and in to Mr Henson's - Arthur Crisp & Mrs Hensons baby have both had measles. Her baby is nt a year old yet, & goes alone all about the house-
I do hope you are well and are getting on nicely - love to Mrs. Heyes and to Mrs Root - By the way - a letter came from Mr Keyes this morning and a deed to be expected - Also the

Wall's Calling Statement - I heard Mr Wilbur was thinking to send for a Mr. Evenage who lives in West Cleveland to come and help in the meetings - Mr Leonard is to preach next Tuesday evening I suppose
Your own Nettie

Nettie P.M.
Feb. 11 1866
Elyria, Ohio, Feb. 11-1866
My dearest Isaac,
I think I will mail a letter in the morning, and then not write again, unless you should write me to do so - I have only had one letter - written Tuesday noon at Indianapolis - I have been to meeting this (Sabbath) evening - Wilder went with me - Mr. Wilber preached - not many out - It rained slightly all the forenoon - Elisa and Wilder & Charlie went to meeting & Sabbath School, It was so rainy & sloppy

that I did not let May go - Tonight it is frozen again - the rain changed to snow before noon,k and it stopped snowing by three o'clock. It rained very hard indeed all night long last night - came through the roof of the little girls room and wet the bed considerably, till I slipped the head away from its placed, and then it made quite a pool on the floor-
Yesterday Irving & Lucy spent the day here - Albina & Charles rode down in P.M. and Albina & I went into Dr's a few minutes to see the sick ones - Mallie

was better, so as to be up and dressed. Edie on the lounge with chickenpox. Willie with measles in prospect, on the bed feeling very badly. Birdie speckled enough, and quite sick - To night I asked Anna how they were - She said Willie was all broken out with measles to day. Birdie about as sick as ever Edie getting over it - Irving just coming down with chickenpox - Mallie gaining. Eliab & Hattie of course are busy enough - I do hope they will all get through nicely.
How thankful should we be that we are all so well - especially

now, while you are away. "Praise God, from whom all blessings flow." I shall feel quite disappointed if I have no letter from you tomorrow - I thought there might be one Saturday night but none came-
Good night, my best and dearest - Your loving Nettie
Monday morn. Cloudy - The trees hung with icicles - We are all well - Baby clinging to my skirts - Anna crying for a slate pencil - So I must comfort them -

Nettie
May 16 1866
St. Louis

                                                                                             Elyria, Ohio
                                                                                              May 16. 1866

My dearest Isaac-

                        It is nearly nine o'clock Wednesday evening. We are all secure and quiet - except that "the rats and the mice they make such a strife" - They are so noisy that it seems sometimes as if big men were travelling about.
  Charlie Rich came over to night and took the soup kettle home for us. It began raining in the night last night, and has been raining all day till about five P.M. Cloudy still. Irving came over here at noon. I sent to Eliab the letter you left for him, and sent to the office the one directed to Wm. Nevins. I went to meeting yesterday morning - good meeting and pretty well attended. Anna came home with me, on her way to spend the day at Charles.

She invited me to go with her and I did, and took little Anna with me. Charles brought us home about four. Quantities of provision for us and the cow also arrived yesterday. We are quite bountifully provided for. 

 The boys have done some cleaning in the cellar. Mr. Wilbur called here yesterday, while I was gone - came in and sat a few minutes with Eliza. Do not know when he returned.
  I think John took a little cold and does not feel quite as well as usual, and he scratched himself on a nail, and the place is very troublesome.
 Thursday morn - All well as usual. I shall go to the meeting this morning. The boys are going down to the office.
                            Great love from
                              Your own Nettie.

Nettie
May 21 1866
Elyria, Monday, May 21
1866
St Louis
My dear Isaac,
I have had two letters from you to day. One which came to me this morning I suppose must have come Saturday night but I did not hear from the office. It simply told of your safe arrival at St Louis, and of the strawberries.
But to night came a nice long account of your place and your ministers and your impression of the progress of St Louis. during the last fifteen years I think you must rather enjoy noting the change comparing "now and then" as well as meeting some old acquaintances.
I felt a little sorry to have gone away so long; but it will doubtless turn out all for the best. I shall lose the chance of going with Mrs.

Furber as her ticket lasts only through the month of May- She and Percie arrived Thursday, the 17th. I went down to morning meeting, and then to the funeral at ten o'clock of the daughter of Mrs. Cramer (Mrs. Dillon) and then dined at Dr's and went in the P. M. to Mrs Wilburs to sew for her, with some twenty five others and when I got home, about seven, found Mrs Furber & Percie here- 
She would stop till next Monday or Tuesday for me to go with her but you probably will not be at home before the last of the week. Percie is quite a nice looking boy- rather small for thirteen. began going to school to day. He is put in the A. class in the Grammar school. 
Mr. Wilbur got home Monday afternoon I think. He came up here Tuesday but I had gone with Anna up to Charles. We took dinner there & Charles brought us home about four. I saw Mr Wilbur Thursday when I went to sew. He said he did not want anything in particular. came up thinking he might see you. He exchanged last Sabbath with Mr Bosworth of Ridgeville. O dear! The sermon

seemed like ashes the confusion with Mr. Wilbur's sermons- Mr Wilbur preached in the evening and gave us real food.
"They say" Mr Gates did nicely in Sabbath School. Also in the three o'clock meeting of which he took charge. Eliza and Emmeline have just come from the Monday evening meeting- The boys do pretty well though they are very full of play, and of course want to be all the time with Percie. I think they try to be good. They take good care of the cow, I think.
Anna seems pretty well now. John is fretful on account of his eye teeth I imagine- and the musquitos have specked his face all over with bites. It was very warm yesterday- but is quite cool again to day.
Eliza has been spending the P.M. at Anna's and Percie went down to supper- Percie is a firm reader. I love to hear him. Guess he has been in the habit

of having pretty much everything he wants. drinks coffee & tea &c-
He seems very careful and steady, and disposed to do right.
All are gone to bed but me. It is past nine, and I think I will go too
Truly and lovingly,
Nettie
-Albina & Charles were here to night all well. Lucy (Eliab's) fell down stairs yesterday, and had pain & vomiting and fainting thereafter, at which they were alarmed and sent for Dr. Sloat - But she got over it, and is about as well as ever today - Anna & Eliza were over there this P.M. Morning meeting suspended since last Saturday. to be recommenced in fall-

Nettie 
May 24 1866
Elyria May 24- 1866
St Louis
My dearest~
I wonder how you are feeling this glorious morning, Whether weary and loosing all patience with the deliberations, long drawn out, of the very dignified and slow moving body you have written about, or getting used to dullness and so bearing with it better. We were all made glad last night with the nice letters- one for me, one for Wilder & one for Charlie. May expects hers will surely come next. The boys were greatly delighted with theirs. I am glad you are going out to the Iron mountain.
Almost wish I were with you to go to- This is splendid weather here, and I hope you have as good.

Mrs Furber spend all the nights here and visits about at her pleasure during days- Percie took his trunk down to Dr's yesterday and will be there for the present. His mother thinks that the best place for him - Dr is not well now -was not out at all Sabbath day - but is better now than then. a sort of billious attack. This has been a week of callers so far. Every afternoon has been quite broken up with them. Mrs. Mussey was in yesterday and Mrs. Twiss. Charles & Albina too with Mr. Kittredge, who arrived yesterday morning and who is on his way out to Iowa to see John and the country - not in very good health, by the way. looks pale & thin. Mrs Furber and Anna & Charles & Albina and Mr K. went over and took tea at Eliab's yesterday - Myself was invited but did not dare walk over. I walked

over Tuesday morning and walked round the grounds, and right home again, and have hardly got over the tired yet. I cannot see why I get so tired walking- This morning we (boys & I) have been working in the "front bed" getting the weeds out and trimming off dead branches and it looks better- but we cannot fasten up the big climbing rose- Mr Ryan hasn't been here since you left, and O! How the whole garden needs him! Things grow. The cucumbers are up nicely_ I sent a lot of asparagus over to Eliabs yesterday. 
The church is being cleaned. They have a portable stove and heat the water on the spot, and I imagine are doing the job thoroughly-
John has just come running out from the bedroom having had his nap and jumped out of his cradle and safely arrived in the dining room

without any assistance. He is rosy and well. so is Anna, and I think May is gaining- Emmeline went home yesterday_ thought she should like to say longer, but her mother came for her-
May has cared for John most of the forenoon very nicely.
I do not know if I had better write again or not. This is the third letter I have written- have received three from you
Your own loving
Nettie 
Thursday night.
Just home from meeting which was full & good. Mrs. Furber and Anna D. went with me. Anna stays till Sat. Another letter from you to night mailed Tuesday- I see not why you get no letter from me. I mailed one the second day after you left. Many ask for you. When you will be back
Good night_ Nettie_

Nettie
May 27 1866
Elyria, May 27- 1866
St Louis
Dear Isaac - 
I wish you could just look in here to the dining room a minute, and see May and Anna and hear them - They are trying to sing very zealously "I'm climbing up Zion's hill" - It is Sabbath morning and, as it rained hard just at meeting time, Mrs. Furber and I are both at home. Wilder and Charlie & Eliza are gone to meeting- It has stopped raining now but is cloudy- sort of April day- It rained more or less all night - and all is fresh & bright out of doors. Mrs. Furber thinks to go tomorrow morning.
John is fretful today - his gums are swelled. Those eye teeth take their own time to get through- Anna Dascomb

went home last night. Dr and Mrs Dascomb both rode over and took supper with us, and then took Anna back with them. Hattie and Maria came over last evening to call for the first time since they moved. They seem very happy, and it is really delightful over there; though they are almost out of patience with the tardy workmen- 2 P.M. We have had dinner and May is reading loud to the others, just now they all want to go to the afternoon prayer meeting. The Ladies sewing society meet at Hiram Hall's next Wednesday. The ladies are in a great hurry to get things ready for a strawberry festival.
Anna (sister Anna) is all tired out. The over exertion of all last winter is just showing itself, and she will have to yield herself up to rest and get over it.
Charlie is reading aloud now and Eliza and Wilder have gone to

three o'clock meeting. I thought perhaps it would do Charlie just as much good to stay and read. 
Eve. 7 o'clock just got John to stay. The dear little fellow - how can I ever be separated from him- He will do well enough without me, but what can I ever do without him~ To night he came from his play and caught my hand and drew me to the little lounge in our bedroom, and motioned me to sit down on it and then got up himself and put my hand on his shoes. I said "Do you want to go in your cradle?" He at once assented, and showed his delight at being understood. I undressed him & he went right to sleep holding my hand. - A book came several days ago - do not know whether I ought to do anything with it or no "The Book of Worship" very finely got up and a pretty good thing, I imagine-
Wilder is just singing "O if my house

is built- upon a rock". He can really sing considerable-
Eliza is gone to meeting- It still rains gently & steadily- I thought I would not venture, on account of my naughty tooth that ache so hard on the slightest provocation. Mrs. Furber sits here reading the last Independent. Percie was here to supper- comes in the morning to help his mother away- Mr & Mrs Rollin De Witt start on Tuesday- Eliab thinks it very doubtful about his getting away this week or until the very last-
Truly and lovingly
Your own Nettie-
Monday morn- Mrs Furber gone. I went to depot with her. Dr has gone to Cleveland too. Cut the asparagus this morning and sent it over to Eliab's-
Every thing planted is nicely up in the garden. And how this rain makes the weeds grow- One corner of our garden at any rate, might remind one of the "field of the slothful" - The garden walks are carpeted with an exceeding rich growth of fine green grass that is exquisite in itself~ but rather out of place- Charley Rich says he might work here some at noon after he gets his job of the curtains through with -

Pembroke N. H.
Friday, July 20- 1866
Mr dearest~
When I got here I found, to my quiet joy, a nice fat letter from Elyria. a long one from yourself and one from Wilder and Charlie for all of which many thanks,- and to day there came another, mailed last Wednesday- I mailed one to you that same day at Yarmouth.
I feel as if you would not come East this summer- I felt sad at first about it. but the more I think it over, the more foolish it seems for me to wish you to come simply to return with me- I shall get on well enough- I wish I had thought to ask you to send by Samuel the pictures you were thinking to bring- perhaps you will do so- I hope Samuel will return through Elyria- because I want a visit with him- The friends here want pictures of Anna very much, as well as of the others- I had to pay half fare for May from Portland to New Market - the first I have paid for her, on the cars

A sharp eyed conductor came in and, after snapping my ticket, looked over to her, and said shortly "How old's your little girl, Madam?" I told him, and he said "half price for her Madam"- so of course I paid it. All were very glad to see us home. Carrie & Franc are both here- Carrie & Sam and May have been blueberrying to day- They are rather scarce every where this season- May had her pint-cup full of nice ones. She is enjoying the stay here very much. It is a pleasant place to visit. one is so heartily welcomed- It is evening now. nine o'clock I wrote the above just after dinner.
Rev, Mr. Carter and wife were here to tea. He is supplying the pulpit here now. He is a Banger graduate- a very pleasant man indeed. Rev Mr Willy (Goffstown) lives in Pembroke now. third door from here. He and his wife called to see me to night- His little girl has been playing with May considerable to day. He looks nicely. I think he is rather fine looking. He spoke of enjoying your society at Goffstown- would like much to see you as agent for Bible Soc. Still says they are trying to have an Episcopal chh. at Goffstown

Have been reading "Ecce Homo" some to day It is very interesting. fascinating style. I wish I had time to read the whole.
Cousin Samuel can get a horse next Monday to take me over to Dunbarton, and cannot get one tomorrow, and they are so anxious to have us stay till Monday that we have concluded to do so, and now it may be that I shall conclude to spend a week from next Sabbath at Dunbarton- not go back to Yarmouth till a week from next Monday. The Dunbarton people want me to spend one Sabbath there, I shall not quite decide about it till I get there. Hope your next letters will be directed to Dunbarton.
Sat morn, July 21
I intended to copy this pencilling but I must write to George this morning & I think I'll send this just as I have jotted it down in odd minutes hoping you will excuse it-This is a lovely morning- The weather has been delightfully cool ever time we came here. People are haying all about. Only about half a crop.
It would be very nice to go home when Samuel Furber goes only I expect it will be later than I shall want to be about getting home- I want to see you all

more and more. Dont think I can stay a very great while more
Tell Wilder May was greatly pleased with her letter. She will answer it soon. O I can not tell anything about how much I should like to get little Anna & John in my arms. To say, nothing of the others-
Mr Willy has just come from Dartmouth commencement. Had an interesting time; but he said not one other of his class was there, and there were over forty of them I think.
Lovingly your 
Nettie-
I am afraid you will be all tired out with the care and keeping awake at night. It seems as if I ought to be there-

Nettie  Pembroke N.H.
July 23rd 1866
Monday eve. July 23, 1866
Pembroke, N.H.
My own dearest,
Here I linger yet detained by rain - We were all ready for an early start this morning, but it has rained steadily all day - We could'nt complain, for we were in a good place, and the rain was much needed, but I hope it will be pleasant tomorrow for it will make our Dunbarton visit short if we stay longer here. We have had a very nice visit here - They have laid themselves out for our comfort. Mary has been happy as a bird - So glad it rained & hopes it will tomorrow Sarah Guilly made me a long call to night. Twenty-one

years ago, she was my scholar when I taught my first school - at Goffstown - She has changed considerably since, as I have -  Saturday we had a nice walk and Rev. Mr Carter went with us - along the  Merrimack -  Yesterday I heard Mr Carter in the morning and cousin Sam in the P.M. - His first attempt at preaching - He did very well - It was rather embarrassing, but he thought he must begin somewhere and Mr Carter asked him to begin here, and thought he had better - We had a grand sing Sabbath night - Uncle has a Bass Viol and it pleases him to use it -  Tuesday morn - Bright and sunny - so we shall start about seven for Dunbarton -

I hope to get a letter from you there -  Lovingly  Nettie  
May sends a card to Anna hoping she will get it - on her birthday

Nettie  Boston
June 21 1866
Thursday June 21 - 1866
U.S. Hotel, Boston
My dearest friend -

 Here we are - five oclock P.M. comfortably established for the night - We have both had a bath, and feel some better for it though we are both pretty tired - I had to sit down to rest first of all, feeling dizzy for some reason - Our room is good size, has sofa, two rockers & c. We have got through nicely though we had an uncomfortable day yesterday - It was warm & close in the cars and May was sick. The poor child vomited four times twice she quite flooded herself and showered the rest of us - though the second time I believe it did not reach Mrs Finn's clothes. I had to go through with quite

performance to get her clothes decently sweet - We happened upon in the car where was water - The cars were pretty full - Our section was reserved in the sleeping car and I paid for it - $3.00, but when it was ready, Mrs Finn thought she would rather go into another common car and sit up - She said she never could sleep in a sleeping car - Neither she nor Mr Finn liked it - Little May slept in her berth very nicely and soundly all night and has felt better ever since. I should have slept only I kept fearing she would be sick again, and hardly dared to get sound asleep, but I rested abundantly - A lady got on board at Erie, who came nearly to Worcester with us - I have not paid anything for May so far - I did not tell you that some stranger, in the night, took the second

second reserved berth, that May & I of course didn't want, and I told the conductor {or the person in charge of sleeping cars} how it was, and he paid me back $1.50 - Our provision basket doesnt grow much lighter - We havent been very hungry - May says she thought that basket wouldnt hold enough to last us - She "wishes we could get there, without going". She does not like riding in the cars. She says "Mother, dont you almost wish you was at home"? I should like to know how you are all prospering- to undress John and get him to sleep and hear little Anna say "moma, love me?, Mama, smile at me". And see Wilder and Charlie and hear that they are all good - Love to them all and to Eliza - Write all about the festival, and what you saw and what you did and what you bought & c  In haste

with great love, your own  Nettie -
How do you all get along, and are you  well, and do things go right about the house - I want to know ever so much -

Nettie   Yarmouth
June 29'66   Yarmouth
Thursday, June 28, 1866
My dearest -
Fanny and I have just come from the meeting of the General Conference at Balto - George was tired and not very well, and had besides a funeral to attend on Wednesday and chose not to go at all - so Fanny & I went  Tuesday afternoon - George had written for a place and had reserved a card of direction & introduction, so we went right to the place, and found it a very nice one indeed with Mr & Mrs Henry Palmer - nice house - nice food, and fine people. Mr Palmer took us all over the city this morning before meeting, in his double carriage - The meetings were some of them rather dull, and some quite interesting - Prof Harris was Moderat or of the meeting - Doct. Pond spoke often, Doct Carruthers & Mr Walker of Portland spoke well - I saw my old teacher of Gilmonton & his wife/ Rev Charles Tenney now of Biddeford - Prof Packard

of Brunswick  I had an introduction to, also to Rev. Mr Haywood of S. Berwick  He wished to be remembered to Mr & Mrs Twiss & Mrs Bunten - Please tell them - I heard him speak - Think the top of his head is like George's.   I wrote to you Monday - Got the third letter from you today, and a nice good long one - You are relieved of some of your arduous duties - will have a little more time to care for your garden & c - Glad of it - I wonder if Mr Mussey is your enemy - I do think much of the exchange in a literary point of view - It is so good to hear from the children - Kiss them all for me, and then they can kiss father for me - George took Fanny and me to ride Monday morning a short distance, and at night we had a long ride, May and I and Mr Wells - He came, on the afternoon train, on the way to Conference - George's horse goes like the wind - His driving is like the driving of John the son of Nimshi  - We had a two seated wagon that George had made arrangements to ride this Summer, when we all go.   Tuesday I had another letter from you - Read report of Dunbarton Centennial - George got one for himself and us. Did I tell you Mr Bittenger of

St. Albans spent the Sabbath here in Yarmouth took tea with us Saturday P.M. His health is not good - rheumatic troubles in part -  May stayed here contentedly while I was gone - She has been quite a good girl - says she read thru chapters in the Bible this morning -  I wish you could manage to get some pictures of the Oberlin men {Professors} some of them, to send or bring to father - He would be very much pleased - Have you tried the children again! What showers you have had. How are the flowers doing?  Have the deeds all come up? I wonder if Eliza remembers the plants in pots - It will be strange if she remembers everything -  The bell rings for meeting, and I will finish in the morning - I do not know as I shall go, but is too dark to write at any rate -  Friday morning - I didnt tell you I saw Rev Mr Clark (William) - It seemed good to see him again and hear him speak  Mrs Hastings, who has lived many years in Boston, says J.C. Pratt was Mayor once.  Commencement at Brunswick Wednesday Aug 1.  Comes just about the night time for you doesn't it?

Examinations precede as usual - Prize declaration of Junior Class, Monday eve, July 30 - but I suppose Wednesday will be the day you come for -  We are going out to walk a little this morning -   Loving  Nettie

Dear Isaac -  Just got yours Mailed 28th as I was directing mine - It is so good to hear from home, and to hear that no body is sick. If you only keep well, how good it will be - Love to Eliza - I wonder if she has made jelly yet, and how she succeeded - Much obliged to Wilder for his letter. I think riding will do us good, for we ride. It is very warm here - though I do not suffer at all from heat. It is thought to be unusually warm for so early in the season - Kiss the children - darling little Don - I should like to hug him -    Truly - Nettie -
Fanny says she never has got a picture of Dr & Mrs DeWitt which was promised when she was at Elyria. Perhaps they will send some

by you.  Do not forget those pictures for father.  He likes pictures as well as ever.  thinks a good deal of getting a good one of little John.
I wish you could get a couple of pairs of those Cleveland stockings, woolen ones to bring to George.  I do not know but you will think I have many wishes.  Will you please bring too, if you can remember it a daguerreotype of father & Mother together wh. is in the parlor somewhere I think.  Father wants to see it. 
Nettie Yarmouth
July 2 1866

Nettie Yarmouth
July 2 1866
Yarmouth
Sabbath July 1 1866
Dearest 
About six o'clock of a mild lovely day. The Sabbaths here seems akin to Dunbarton Sabbaths for quietude disturbed only by bird, music, and, at meeting time, by the coming of country carriages to the old fashioned church. Were you ever inside it?  The high pews, with dark green fronts give it a sombre appearance. We walk in, facing the congregation. Pulpit at the entrance.  One needs to remove? ones-self to meet the eyes on entering.  I feel as if it were Sabbath all the week.  There is such a sense of rest of "occupation gone"  I don't think I fully enjoy it yet.  Though I would'nt have your support I am in the least unhappy.  I do not think I have felt for some months the light heartedness.
Sha'nt you be here by the 28th? or cannot you tell yet! Love to all. At Dr's and  Eliabs too.

I once did.  There has been a sort of weight on my spirits that I can not hardly describe.  Some shadow has seemed hanging over me.  I feel as if, now I am away from my own place I ought to be dong some good to somebody.  I know you will pray that I may not be useless, and that God may watch over us all while we are separated. May is very good usually. She was much interested in the morning sermon. the subject was the unjust  Judges, text, Luke 18; 1-8.  also, in the scripture reading &  comments, George is reading Sam (1st) in course, and commenting thereon, for the Sabbath mornings scripture lesson.  Text  This P.M."Among whom ye shine as lights" After sermon, the communion service. About one hundred and fifty communicants.  The audience to day numbered three hundred twenty, and was about as usual in good weather.  The singing is fine Young Dr. Burbank

is leader, his wife, organist, his sister one of the chief singers the choir is large some twenty five there today.  Father has been for several days suffering from diarrhea.  Was not able to go to church this morning; & Since we came from meeting, Fanny has read the morning sermon aloud to him. May thinks she could understand it all And the chapter in the Bible too.  She had read three chapters to me since the afternoon service. Monday morn.  Another delightful morning.  I should like to help you eat strawberries & green peas. I havent seen either, save .half a dozen wild strawberries we found when we rode Saturday. We found any quantity of wintergreen leaves- I think May gains some in health though she is very sallow. She wonders what awakes her "sleep and well have and so ugly at home". She says she kept waking up at home, but

here she goes to sleep and when she wakes again is astonished to find it morning.  She eats exceedingly. I am almost ashamed sometimes.  I think H.C.S. must be Horace Starr - or rather I can think of no one, unless it be he.
Friday morning I had a long walk and after supper we had a long ride  I cut & made a white cape for May that day-  I have bought a new hat for May, too.  She soiled hers on the journey, and I found it.  Looked rather behind other girls here, and quite dark in color for summer.  I paid $4.66.  Father has been unwell for several days with diarrhea but is better again.  Saturday May and I had a ride in the morning and after supper again.  May enjoyed the riding very much.  Rev & Mrs Abbott of the other church called Saturday
very pleasant people. May has gone riding with George now. Fanny is at work in her garden  a little taking up tulip bulbs.  I have written to Jenny this morning - got up at five-  Letter from cousin Franc  Saturday  The vacation begins the 16 of July or about then.  and George thinks to spend the 22nd in Dunbarton if nothing happens-  and the Monday after to go to Pembroke for a day or two 

Loving Nettie

Thursday, July 5 1866
My dearest Isaac -  I mailed a letter to you Monday, just after having received a nice long one from you - I had a letter from Mrs Finn what day also  She seemed to be having a fine time  Was going to the beautiful Lake George the next day - I wrote to her the next day in reply - Monday after supper George & Father and I rode to the Cemetery - several ladies called -   Tuesday - Read some and had a long talk with father who is still troubled with his diarrhea, and seems weak & easily exhausted - still he is about the house & walks out doors a short distance -  Callers again - After supper George & Fanny went to see a sick young man {consumption} George says there is always some one, usually a young person, that is dying of consumption  He has attended the funeral of one young lady, about twenty, since I came.    Yesterday, Wednesday, July 4 - May had a long ride in the morning, and in the P.M. George took Fanny & me to Freeport for the ride - some thirteen miles there & back - Mr & Mrs Shipley called in the evening - H was once pastor here - pleasant man - Has a fine daughter who teaches in Blairsville Penn. She is now at home for vacation. She

reminds one of Dr Dascombs nurse. There was a great amount of riding yesterday - Many went to Portland to a great celebration, - and the Baptist S.S. had Picnic in the woods towards Freeport - This is a great place for fast horses - every night after supper there is a constant stream of carriages, with men, women and children, going at full speed - There is an Arnie Ruhannah Mitchel here - He brought George a load of chips yesterday - He gave the hauling and the shipyard gave the chips - Mr Loring, a pleasant dealer, owner of Mills, brought a barrel of flour the other day which is quite a present - now, as flour is $20.00 per bbl - Steak here is .25 per Lb. Mutton .18 - Isn't it more than in Elyria? May is sitting by me, reading aloud from "Little Prudy's Dotty Dimple'. She has read in her bible and a little in Pilgrim's Progress - It is before breakfast, - and we are upstairs in our room - Do you know it is fourteen years ago today! I think God has been very good indeed to us  We have had some very sad times, but more glad ones - It seemed to me that I could love God, as my dear father and kind  friends, more than ever this morning -  I do wonder every day how you are getting on at home - Nobody but

Eliza to do anything for you - Do the children seem to have clothes enough, and to keep whole - Perhaps Eliza can can some strawberries - She may need some more glass cans (self sealers) - Anna will be willing to oversee anything that need looking after - Two weeks yesterday since I left home - Give love to Eliza. Does she get lonesome & homesick any?   Ten oclock A.M. There was an awful fire in Portland last night - burning over about one hundred acres - including the business part of the city - All the city buildings - the Post Office  the Printing offices, three Congregational Churches - including Dr Carruthers, Insurance offices all but two, turning out of house &  home at least five hundred  families - Large sugar refining was burnt - A Mr Chandler called this morning who had just come from Portland - His home was burned and every thing in it - only what he could draw away on a wheelbarrow. The sky was very red in that direction last night -, and the glare sometimes lighted our rooms - but we knew nothing definite till this morning - A good many Yarmouth people went to Portland staying over to see the evening fireworks - They got fire worked beyond their expectation - I do not know but I am a sufferer, for I think there might be a letter

there from you - I had one Monday, and thought to get another yesterday or today -  I have written this with little Georgie in my arms - I took him upstairs with me to relieve his Mother a little -   I would write to the boys, but I ought not to spend too much time writing, and I have written considerable since I came here - Ever so much love to all  From yours ever  Nettie

Nettie  Yarmouth
July 7 1866
Yarmouth
Sat. July 7 - 1866
Dear Isaac -

It does seem as if I had been from my home a very long time - two weeks last Wednesday - I have written five times, and have today received the sixth letter from you - It does me more good than I can tell , to get the letters - The one that came today was the story of your "fourth", with its haps and mishaps - &  I laughed till I cried over it. What a nice time you had - I should have enjoyed it so very much - I wish I could have looked at you all a few minutes - I should like to have seen just how the children looked and behaved and enjoyed as doubtless they did to the utmost.

I think they are given to having such good times when I am gone - but I am enjoying my visit much, though it is extremely warm and has been most of the time. George says he never knew so warm weather in Yarmouth - It seems to me I have not in years felt the heat so much. And May and I both have a small proportion of thin clothing - You know I was thinking to come a month earlier than we did come. You have heard by the Jaspers of the enormous fire in Portland - 3000 families homeless - Father and George rode in this morning to behold the ruins - The fire is still burning in some places - George says it looks like a forest of chimneys - They saw the houseless ones going to the old City Hall, with their pails to be filled with breakfast - Munjoy Hill is covered with tents - Father was quite lost

he missed the old landmarks. I must stop and help May go to bed -  She is gone to sleep - so I'll write a little more - Dr Carruthers lost his church and his house. He was sick and had to be moved three times it is said - No one thought of the flames spreading so, and much furniture that had been moved, had to be moved again or was burned. It burned over two hundred acres, instead of one, as I wrote, being one third of the whole territory. We will send you the Portland Press of the 7th There was none on the 5th - On the sixth a single page about one foot square, sent to Boston to be printed - Other places are constantly sending help to the sufferers - Quite a number are in Yarmouth with relations and friends - Fanny and I are expecting to go to see the ruins the first of next week.  I do hope little Don will not get sick under a currant bush again - May seems to feel well, and eats abundantly.

She frisks about with considerable life and seems to enjoy herself very much - But she is sallow still - Fanny thinks homeopathy would do her good - But I hesitate about giving her medicine when she seems to feel so well - Father has his old diarrhea trouble - hardly sleeps at all some nights - is up and down all night long - He has very little strength
I have had two letters from Mrs. Finn. Please tell Mrs. Furber that Dr Colby and his wife were both buried the last day of June, at Concord - Both had been sick a long time
P.M. It must be rather a sad sabbath at Portland - It is said that neither of the Cong. Churches that are Burnt out are able to rebuild unless by uniting. - O so warm it is to day - really oppressive it makes ones head ache - But over two hundred at meeting this P.M. and none yet this morning - I do like the singing here. They use the Sabbath Hymn Book V Sabbath Hymn & Tune Book  I did not go out this forenoon -  When May came home I asked her for the temp She said it was "He came unto his own and his own received him not" -  She gave we girls an idea of the sermon - She says she can understand such sermons - She usually gets hold of the main idea, showing that she has understood the design & point of the discourse
Your own loving Nettie

Monday morn July 9
About my health it is certainly better than when I left home; But it is too warm for one to feel much energy - It seems cooler this morning, and I hope it will prove to be so and keep so - Father is better this morning George & Fanny & Mrs Hastings and boy & I are going into Portland this morning just to ride about and view the desolation of the beautiful forest city. About going home - Please write when you can best come? George is to preach in Dunbarton the last Sab. in July Our plan is to go to

Pembroke Sunday July 23 Stay a day or two there and then the rest of the week at Dunbarton, and I, with Mary, return to Yarmouth on Saturday 28 - if you get here that day, as I rather planned to have you. George intended to spend the fourth weekend of the fifth Sabbath at Dunbarton, but they were supplied that day before he wrote. We almost concluded to give up going, but thought they would be disappointed. If you do not get here that Sat. I will stay and come with George the next Monday. This is what we have talked over. After that I am ready for home - I thought I would write to Almeda, and see if she is going out to Elyria this Fall. If not we must go to see her.

Nettie 
Yarmouth
July 11 1866

                                                                                                Yarmouth, Maine
                                                                                                  Wednesday, July 11, 1866

My very dearest -

       I mailed a letter Monday telling of our plan about Dunbarton but it is all overturned so far as George is concerned.  There is to be a great council to install Rev. Mr. Fenn at Portland the week we were thinking to go to D. We were going at that time because then was the time they wanted George to preach so now I mean to go to Pembroke next week Wednesday July 18 and back here the first part of the next week, ready to see you, going to Dunbarton to spend the Sabbath. Cous. Sam. will take me over. May and Georgie have been to ride this morning with uncle George, and then after father and I went, and were gone just one hour. It is a fine, breezy morning. The weather has been fine ever since I came. May says there is only one baby in the world that is better than Georgie. George think, in that case, he and ? had better be

satisfied. We went to Portland as we expected last Monday. It is a sad sight. It took a full hour to ride over the burnt district, not stopping at all. There was a very strong wind at the time of the fire, and it seems as if nothing could arrest its progress - Cinders were picked up in Yarmouth the next morning. It was so sad to see the ruined trees. We rode the whole length of streets that, before the fire, were lined with tall Elms that shaded elegant residences on either side - now nothing is left but ruins - tall chimneys scorched & blackened trees, and now and then a part of the wall of a brick building.
