Not a vestage of Dr. Carruthers church but some cross beams lying in the sand. The walls of the elegant city buildings are mostly standing, but entirely cleaned out within, and cracked from top to bottom in varis places. The Post Office of stone is in such a condition that they do business in it, and have all the while. Everything all around it is gone. It was said to be a fine sight to see the flames roll up against it, time and again without seeming to have power to harm it. The glass throughout the building is all gone. What a world of work to clean away the rubbish. There were 25 men in one place at work

scraping the bricks to use again. That was at Brown's sugar refinery. The smell of burnt sugar was almost suffocating. When riding over the ruins I thought there cannot be much of Portland left - but - as we rode over what is standing, I thought there was considerable, - though most of the business part is gone. But they are still in a state of great insecurity, not daring to sleep at night - a gang of robbers from Boston & N. York have been there ever since the fire, trying to set fire again for the sake of plunder. They tried to set fire to two churches on Sabbath during worship. There are soldiers the whole length of state street, and they keep guard, specially over the streets where the houses are full of treasure. We stopped in a fine grove in Falmouth, on the way home, and had a picnic dinner, and enjoyed it much. May found half a dozen blueberries the first of the season, I guess. We got home about four P.M. Miss Lucy Littlefield of Bangor was here to supper. She was an old school mate of Jenny's. Yesterday Mrs. Busbank was here - a very fine old lady indeed. After supper George took May & me and rode to Cumberland and back - delightful ride.

I want much to hear when you are coming. Wish I could hear this before going to Pembroke.

  Well, this must to the Office go. Great love to all. Father wants you to stay here as long as possible as do the rest.
         Your own
                          Nettie

Nettie Yarmouth Friday July 13-1866
July 13 1866
Dearest, -

     Yours of July 6 and 8 came yesterday P.M. What rainy weather you have, and here is has not rained enough to lay the dust since I came, three weeks ago this day. The birds are singing delightfully this morning. There is a warm wind and the air so sultry that one feels languished. May & I have had a ride, and she is gone now with her uncle. She enjoys the riding exceedingly.
 I know it is quite an undertaking to leave the children - the older ones especially. I had thought that Wilder perhaps would be permitted to stay with Charles, and Charlie, if he was faithful about the chores, could stay with Percie some of the time. Perhaps Percie might spend the nights with Charlie at our house, and Charlie go to Drs' with him for the day. But you can plan better than I. I could

go back alone, but should enjoy so much having you come, if you can arrange it, and I guess with Anna's help you can.

 May looked rather sorry & sad when the last letter came and there was nothing directed to her. She is out of doors a good part of the time. She has eaten very little cake or candy. She has bought pea nuts several times. She reads some every day and usually writes some. She has been reading Pilgrims Prog. & the Little Prudy  Books. I bought some gingham and am making a dress for her, a cool one for this very warm weather. Father thinks there never was such warm weather in Yarmouth before.
  Fanny has raspberry shrub that is very nice to drink, diluted with water. The juice is squeezed from the berries. 1 Lb sugar to 1 pint juice, just as for jelly, and boiled 15 minutes, stirring the while & then bottled.
                    In haste your own Nettie.

Nettie Yarmouth Me
July 18 1866

                                                                                                                  Yarmouth, Maine
                                                                                                               Wednesday, July 18, 1866

My very dear Isaac,-

             I have just received and read yours of the 11 & 12, & it is all so good, except about your coming. I had rather made up my mind upon seeing you next week, and my eyes would grow a little dim over it. I confess that I should feel a good deal of anxiety about home matters after you leave, and should be in some haste to set our faces homeward. And on the other hand, I dread the journey home alone, though I am willing to undertake it, & I do not like to give up the enjoyment I had promised myself in visiting with you - and seeing you sooner. I will simply suggest your bringing Wilder with you - If you really think it would not be best for you to come, I can return by myself - go down to

Boston and stay as I did when we came, over night. I suppose if you come you could not stay for much of a visit.

It does me good to hear so good news from the children. Give love to Eliza. Wonder if she find any trouble in knowing "what to get for dinner"
   Fanny and George are right here, shelling peas, with May to help. They will be disappointed if you do not come. May and I have George's valise all ready packed to go to Pembroke. We expect to go this P.M. May felt as if she wanted to see Dunbarton and I thought on the whole I'd like to have her.
  I am glad John likes a hat. He is more likely to keep one on this head when out doors. Little Georgie here throws his off so fast as it can be put on- sometimes at least. He has a passion for driving a horse - held the reins some time yesterday when riding - did not like to give them up at all. It rains occasionally today, but is very warm still. I have bought & made a new gingham

Dunbarton, July 26, 1866

My dearest -

 I wish you were home this most lovely of mornings. The sunshine, the singing of birds, and the delicious air, with the views that never can anywhere be surpassed, it seems to me, make it glorious. Here, at Dea Parker's, the view is very extensive. Kearsarge, Monadnock and the White Mountains can be seen, as well as the ranges of smaller hills. I mailed a letter to you at Concord Tuesday morning on the way here. But I have not heard from you since last Friday, almost a week. I think there must be a letter for me at the office but- we have not heard from there, since I came. It has been rather hard to be patient. Dea Parker says he will go this P.M. to the office & I shall go to, and make calls and perhaps spend the night somewhere. There is a house full of company here

always is in summer I guess. There are seven, beside their own family of seven. I rode last night over to Mr. John Buntin's - saw Mrs. Buntin and the children and Miss Elsie. They are all well. Miss Elsie said she did not know but she felt as well as ever. The warm weather suits her. The children look bright and healthy. Sam spent about two hours riding about in Concord. It has changed and improved much. Nice State House and New Business College beside great improvements in residences. I enjoyed the ride very much.

 But after all, I believe I feel a little homesick. I do long to be home again.
 Two daughters of Leonard Parker are here spending vacation. A sister of Mrs. Parker and two lady acquaintances one from New York and one from near Hartford. I suppose if you do not come to go with me home, it will not of course be best for me to go to Hartford to see Hattie. I suppose I ought to write to her, so she need not be expecting. I may go back to Yarmouth Saturday cannot tell yet.
                                          Your own
                                                           Nettie.

It is little Anna's birthday - tell the children Mother thinks of them many times a day.

Nettie Dunbarton                                                                                                      Dunbarton
July 30 1866                                                                                               Sabbath July 29, 1866
Dearest,

    I have not heard from you for a week and two or three days. I mailed a letter Tuesday and one Thursday last. Thursday night, I went home with Mrs. Kimball, and Friday she came up to the meeting house with me and we made five calls and took tea at Charles Kimball's.  I only wish you were here too.
  I have a nice time seeing old friends. Mr. L.R. Mills came for me yesterday morning and I took dinner there. Mr. Tafford came there for me just after dinner and I took supper there with Capt. Stinson & wife and Col. Kent & wife. Came to Capt. Whipple's in the Eve. to spend sabbath - home with John Kimball's people tomorrow night to start for Manchester & Yarmouth Tuesday.

Monday morn. A Delightful morning. I should have started for Yarmouth today only May's shawl was left at Dea Parker's and they forgot to bring it to meeting yesterday, and I have to wait a day to get it. Mrs. William Whipple is coming for me after dinner and she will take me to Mr. Ryder's, and Charles Ryder will take me to John Kimball's to night. He thinks Ryder would carry me to Manchester from his house but some of my things are at John Kimball's. It is a little unpleasant with all the pleasant to be toted about in this way, but I enjoy seeing the people.

  But I begin to be impatient to be home. It seems sometimes as if I could hardly wait. I suppose I must stay and see father a little more. They want me to go to Westboro', but I think I cannot. I feel sorry not to go to day to Yarmouth, but I thought the shawl was worth waiting a day for. Capt. Whipple seems just as ever wants to see you. The hills here are grand - no scenery better. Loving Nettie.
